text:
My Apache is configured to use 2 ports: 80 and 2002. I created many virtual 
hosts for my daily use, but if I use the right configuration and make the first 
virtual host the default (*), the 9th virtual host become the default for the 
inexistent host requests using the 2002 port (in my case).

E.g.: I have 30 virtual hosts, the default for no defined virtual host is the 
1st. When I access blablabla.wsrv.cjb.net:2002, instead of viewing the 1st 
virtual host, I see the 9th. However, when I access blablabla.wsrv.cjb.net I 
see the right page (1st virtual host).
creator: wesleygoku@hotmail.com
nd@perlig.de
text:
I'd say, the behaviour is correct. It seems your're confusing name based VHs and
IP-based VHs. Can you attach your configuration to investigate further?

creator: wesleygoku@hotmail.com
text:
I couldn't find a way to upload the file, so I hosted it in my professional 
hosting, check the link below:

http://wstec.net/tmp/httpd.conf.txt

If you see, I am using NameVirtualHost for every VirtualHost I create.

Please see
http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/vhosts/name-based.html#using
where you will see that you want only ONE NameVirtualHost directive for each
IP/Port combination, not one for each VirtualHost section.  You should be
getting a bunch of error messages about "no virtual hosts defined for
namevirtualhost" or something similar in your error log.
creator: slive@apache.org
wesleygoku@hotmail.com
text:
In fact I was, until I haven't changed all ServerName to include the ports and 
match the NameVirtualHost directive.

VirtualHost documentation for Name-Based VHs isn't so explaining...

I'm sorry, now I've seen the documentation and think the problem was solved.

Thanks for helping! :-)
creator: wesleygoku@hotmail.com
